text.value:
Start the timer when the child reads the first letter. There are checkboxes for each letter on the next page. Follow along with the child and check correct words. Count self-corrections as correct.
You may uncheck letters after they have been checked.
Remember the number of the last character read.
Enter the number of the last character spoken
Enter "0" for early finish; "100" if the student read all letters
Enter the time left on the stopwatch in seconds
Range: 0 to 60 seconds (enter 0 seconds if the student did not finish)
At each step, please ask the student "What are the sounds in _______?" Say each word twice. Mark correctly identified sounds. Leave incorrectly identified or skipped sounds unchecked.
Check here if the student had no correct response on the first five words (ends exercise).

This is the initial sound identification exercise. Ask the student "What is the first sound in ____?" Say each word twice and record the student's response as "correct," "incorrect," or "no response."
Check here if the student did not answer any of the first five words correctly (ends exercise).
Ask the student to pronounce the sound of each letter on the laminated sheet. Mark correctly pronounced letter sounds.
Remember the number of the last letter read.
Enter the number of the last letter spoken
Enter "0" for early finish; "100" if the student read all letters
Enter the time left on the stopwatch

Show the student the sheet of familiar words. Start the timer when the student reads the first word and mark correctly pronounced words.
After 60 seconds, say "Stop," and record the number of the final word read.
Remember the number of the last word read or attempted.
Enter the number of the last word read or attempted
Enter "0" for early finish if the student failed to correctly read the first 5 words; "50" if the student read all words
Enter the time left on the stopwatch in seconds

Show the student the sheet of unfamiliar nonwords. Start the timer when the student reads the first word and mark correctly pronounced nonwords.
After 60 seconds, say "Stop," and record the number of the final nonword read.
Remember the number of the last word read or attempted.
Enter the number of the last word read or attempted
Enter "0" for early finish if the student failed to correctly read the first 5 words; "50" if the student read all words
Enter the time left on the stopwatch in seconds

Ask the child to read aloud the story on the student form. Start the time when the child reads the first word. When 60 seconds are up, remove the passage from in front of the child and ask the follow-up questions.
Mark correctly pronounced words in the passage.
Remember the number of the last word the child was reading when 60 seconds are up.
Enter the number of the last word the student read before time was up.
Enter "0" to indicate an "early stop" if the student did not read any of the first ten words correctly. Enter 60 if the student finished the entire story.
How many seconds were left on the stopwatch when the student finished reading the story?
Enter "0" if the child did not finish.
Student did not read this part of the story
How many people are in Pat's family?
Answers: four; mother, father, Sam, Pat
Sam's family was happy. Then something happened. What was it?
Where did the snake bite Sam? How did Sam get well?
Answers: leg | his mother helped him; put wet cloths and leaves on his leg
What made the family happy again? What do you think happened to the snake?
Answers: Sam was healed | ran off; Pat or father killed it; or any reasonable answer

Read the story on the next page aloud to the child (only one at a time), slowly (about 1 word per second). Say: "I'm going to read you a short story aloud ONCE and then ask you some questions. Please listen carefully and answer the questions as best you can. Do you understand what you are to do?"
Read this story aloud to the child:

The gray duckling fell in the mud. "Help me," she cried. A green frog came to help, but he fell in too. "What now?" asked the frog. "I see something that leads to land!" the duckling replied. They both climbed on the log. "We are saved!" they shouted.
Who fell in the mud last?
What did the duckling see that was important?
How did the frog and the duck get out of the mud?
Why do you think the frog and the duck are friends?
